Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2009 04:30PM donsuzbee wrote: Having had a mod rad mastectomy in 1993, I went back to my normal, everyday way of life - carried in the groceries, did all the cleaning - lifting, carrying, etc.  When my grandson was born end of 1993, I took care of him while his mom worked and lifted him - first when he weighed 5 pounds then when he weighed 20 pounds and on. In 2001 I had a recurrance and had radiation - over an implant.  Still kept on keeping on as no one told me not to "lift........"  In 2003 I developed full blown upper right quadrant LE.  20 PT sessions per year (per my insurance) 2003, 2004, 2005, 2006/compression garments/self massage and I am still right back where I started.  My point is I don't believe the weight lifting will help everyone maybe just a very few.  And as we all know we all get different treatment from diagnosis of BC on.  In one of the media articles a Dr was quoted as saying LE is less likely to happen with the advances in ways to do surgery.  Yes, my daughter in DC called me to ask me if I had seen the article and "mom this will really help you!"   She forgets that I did not simply have 1 surgical procedure but 4 in the same area.  As for "controlled" LE I too would sure like to know what that is and how you get it!!!!!!! God bless! Susan B.
Posts.Title: They did it! lionessdoe kira

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2013 06:32PM donsuzbee wrote: Not sure this will be of any connection. At my last PET scan my right shoulder (LE in upper right quadrant, especially arm) "lit up" greatrr than my mets in my spine. Referred to a rheumatologist and following an MRI I was diagnosed with impingment syndrome. The bone that comes around from your back and meets your collarbone at the shoulder are impinged where they come together. First course of treatment was to have the bone at the connection shaved, but no surgery for us mets people. Steroid injection then done. WHOLE DIFFERENT STORY NOW. No needle sticks in L E. The doctor is not always right. He said it would be ok, but Cellulitis came along and put me in the hospital for 4 days. Maybe you should be checked for something further in that shoulder.Ihad the pain for about 6 months, but thought it went with the "territory" Never dreamed it could be impinged.  I shared the Cellulitis art only to emphsize our need to be careful with LE.

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2009 07:13PM donsuzbee wrote: Binney, Thank you so much for replying to my question. Unfortunately I have tried all of the things you recommended. I have a tribute sleeve and vest that attaches, but you are right it is tooooooooo uncomfortable to wear the vest. I have been dealing with LE since 2002, having gone to therapy 4 times. Do home massage and wear the bandaging and tribute sleeve. When the advice is given that loosing weight helps - I can tell you that is right. I need to lose the 20 pounds I have put on. I had a right nephrectomy due to kidney cancer in July 2007 and my arm sort of took a back seat. I am trying to be disciplined again about taking care of it. But, I have come to the conclusion, that I will never see an arm the size of my left one again. So am trying to just focus on "maintaining" where I am. You are a blessing to the Breast Cancer world! Susan B.

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 06:27PM donsuzbee wrote: This seems to be the biggest question we all face as we grow older!!!!!!   My friend told me when I turned 65 - "now you can stand under the golden arches, and I don't mean McDonald's."  Not so sure the arches are golden.  Just will share my own experience.  As long as I had the opportunity for other insurance I didn't have to go on Medicare at 65.  Since I worked until I was 67 I stayed on my employer's insurance.  Went on Medicare at 67 and got a Medicare advantage plan as my supplement.  Knowing what to get was harder than 1980's when AT&T had to disband due to being a monopoly.  It was my job with the company I was with the get us a new phone service.  Not sure now which was harder!  So far ok with Medicare and supplement advantage plan except for physical therapy which I should have due to lymphedema.  Also Medicare does not pay for lymphedema garments.  I have a friend whose mom was to have another PET Scan and Medicare would not approve it as it would have been her 3rd in a year.  The mom had not been given much longer to live so that also was part of why Medicare refused the 3rd PET.  If you have been on SSDI you must really know the ropes at getting things done.  I wish you the very best at making your decision. Susan
Posts.Title: First SSDI, now MEDICARE questions Analemma Sue-61

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2014 07:15PM donsuzbee wrote: Hello. Mets to spine getting more under control since I started the Affinitor/Aromisin meds. Plus continuing Xgeva monthly injection. Tumor on left adrenal gland DX 2013. Not responding as quickly as Onc would like so March 31 finished 8 Stereotactical Radiation Surgery treatments followed by PET scan. Tumor reduced by 2/3. At age 73 I just keep rolling along these 21 years of breast cancer with renal cell carcinoma meaning right nephrectomy 7 years ago.  All of you give me encouragement to do what needs to be done.

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2010 12:20AM donsuzbee wrote: Just diagnosed with mets to spine.  In T4, T14 & L4 vertebrae.  I had renal cell carcinoma 3 years ago (right kidney removed), so I had to have a biopsy to make sure the mets were breast cancer mets not kidney cancer mets.  Every 28 days I will have  45 mg Aredia infusion and 2 250mg Faslodex injections.  Original dx 1993, right mod rad mastectomy, local recur 2001 and now the mets.  Each time before I focused on my family handling the diagnosis.  This time I need to focus on me.  Hope I'm not being selfish!!!!!! God bless! Susan
Posts.Title: where are your bone mets located?? skigrl lady4law

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2009 04:33AM donsuzbee wrote: Oh my gosh!!! Where were you ladies 3 years ago when I was told I possibly had PMPS - Post Mastectomy Pain Syndrom - by my PT. Probably I do. But the R-IBP sounds more like what I have. On having a recurrance I had the normal - at the time - 30 rounds of rads + 5 boosts. But since this was a recurrance I had already had an implant following the original mastectomy. The radiologist said at the beginning the rads that my implant may not make it thru the rads. And sure enough the implant was fried. I had to have it removed so this was the 4th surgery in the same place - mod rad mastectomy, expander, implant, remove implant. With LE in my upper right quadrant, some days I literally cannot stand the pain. I take tylenol with codeine and then do absolutely nothing on those days. If I use my right arm much at all it stirs up the pain. My wonderful husband does most of the cleaning and cooking. Thank you for being here!!!!!! Susan B.

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2009 02:48PM donsuzbee wrote: The first time I had cellulitis it was a combination staph/strep. I had had my prophylactic mastectomy in July, had then ran a fever 3 days after surgery. Was treated for a urinary tract infection. But the doctor was of the opinion that the staph stayed in my body. Second time of cellulitis I had visited my daughter in the hospital. The doctor was of the opinion that I picked up the staph there even though I did not touch anything, but my LE was very swollen in my whole upper right quadrant. The red hot spot was actually on my neck and breast area. It had not gone down into my arm yet. Thank you Lord!!!!! Incidentally, I have since learned that what was thought to be urinary tract infections is simply my body at age 68 and having been on Femara for 7 years - thus I am absolutely wiped out of estrogen. I had a pap test a year ago even though I have had a hysterectomy the gynocologist said I needed to have one. It came back questionable. The Gyn said I will have questionable pap tests the rest of my life due to lack of estrogen and will probably always have urine tests that show urinary tract infection, even though I don't actually have one. I actually felt relieved at that as my urine tests kept coming back positive for infection even though I had no symptoms or anything. One part of the test was negative and one part positive so at first it was thought I had a lot of urinary tract infections. Susan B.
Posts.Title: Cellulitis rears it's ugly head! JO-5 JO-5

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2009 11:25PM donsuzbee wrote: I live in GA so stay indoors all summer as I have arm and truncal LE. But, went to IL to attend my 93 year old aunt's funeral. Very hot at the grave site and sunny. On our way to the dinner after, we stopped at my son's house as he had a cold pak he kept in the freezer that was a soft one - not hard like the ones for coolers. I put it under my blouse and it cooled me off and relieved my le somewhat. Wish I had done that before the funeral. Not sure this is appropriate technique but it sure helped in an emergency. SusanB.

AND I tell them. Pink arms would draw all the more attention. Let's not waste this "pink" LOL! Susan

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2009 08:03PM donsuzbee wrote: Wow! your post brought back memories! and of a time of dealing with cellulitis. Last July 1 I was visiting my son in IL and came down with the dreaded cellulitis. Red, Red and fever of 102. At 5am my son is taking me to the hospital and as we are driving down the road he says very seriously: "Mom, I have something to tell you." I am thinking, OMG! what now!!!!!!! It turns out that a friend of his was starting residency that day and he knew there would be a lot of new residents. I did have one of the new ones, but she was awesome. I think being a BC survivor, LE, kidney cancer survivor with only 1 kidney that wasn't working up to par and now cellulitis that I was a case study for her and she was fascinated. Susan B.
